metadata.title: Crested Auklets - Alaska Sea Grant Radio Show
metadata.description:
Finding a suitable mate is a challenge for just about every species. If you're a seabird like the crested auklet, finding a partner may be as simple as being good at keeping
parasites off your body. Doug Schneider has more, in this week's Arctic Science Journeys Radio.
metadata.notes:
Purpose: Alaska's Aleutian Islands stand like lush, green sentinels overlooking the Bering Sea. Their massive cliffs are an oasis amid a vast, lonely ocean, and are home to a variety
of seabirds. The most recognizable is probably the tufted puffin. These islands also are home to colonies of shearwaters, kittiwakes, and crested auklets. At seven inches in length, crested auklets aren't big. But what they lack in size, they more than make up for in number. Hector Douglas is a graduate student who studies crested auklets at the
University of Alaska Fairbanks.

Status: Complete

Maintenance frequency: None Planned
